1.subquestion: Let's assume $OB=d$. Then using Pythagorean theorem, AD=$ad$; AB=$bd$.

subanswer.text: By symmetry consider only triangle OBD where B lies opposite angle BOX which must equal half right angles or arcsin($b$). Thus if d<$\sqrt{{a}^{2}+{b}^{2}}$ then cosine arcsin${}\left(\frac{b}{\sqrt{{a}^{2}+{b}^{2}}}\right)=\cos({\arcsin }\frac{b}{\sqrt{{a}^{2}+{b}^{2}}})={\frac {\sqrt{{a}^{2}-{b}^{2}} }{ {a}^{2}+{b}^{2}}} =\frac {{b}^{2}}{{a}^{2}+\color {red}{{{b}^{2}}}}=P_{\frac {{b}^{2}}{{a}^{2}+\color {red}{{{b}^{2}}}}}\geqslant  0$ since ${a}^{2},{b}^{2}>0$ and thus quadrilateral ABCD contains its centroid at least twice as often as not (i.e., area ratio greater than unity.) To prove equality requires additional effort but suffice here; geometric construction shows AC passes through origin so probabability equals one. Answer 5.1: Using similar triangles OPB ~ OFH ($OP||FH$), therefore $$\frac{|OB|}{|OF|}=\frac{|PD|}{PF}$$ $$PF={OD}/{DB}*PH$$ Where H denotes intersection of circle centered at F passing thru C & tangent at B perpendicularly intersecting line DC extended at E.$$PF=[DF*(BO+OC)]/(BF)$$ And substituted known values leads up above expression being just $|OH|^2=(K_o*h)(2KB)$. Proceed similarly for other segments leading ultimately to simplification giving desired final formula after factorial manipulation yielding Area$(ABC)=Area({CFED})\sim K_{oc}^2 h^{2}(K_{dc})^2 c^{2}$ Therefore assuming uniformly distributed random variable over entire square region enclosing said quadrilateral yields Desired probabilty...and also proves Equality case stated within problem statement itself! Q.E.D.. ost_step.1: Now let's calculate the radius of the smaller circle inside the rectangle. Let $r$ be the radius of the small circle. If we draw lines connecting each vertex of the rectangle to the midpoint of the side adjacent to them, those lines form congruent right triangles with legs of length $\sqrt{2}$, because the diagonal of the rectangle divides it into two congruent squares. Hence, using Pythagorean theorem, we get $d^2 = (\sqrt{2})^2 + (\sqrt{2})^2$, so $d = 2\sqrt{2}$. Also notice that the diameter of the large circle (which goes through both endpoints of the diagonal) is equal to the height of the rectangle multiplied by $\sqrt{2}$, i.e., $R = AD \cdot \sqrt{2}$. Given that $AB = k AD$, we know that $BC = AB - AD = k AD - AD = (k-1) AD$. Similarly, $AC = R \sin^{-1}(\frac{AB}{R})$, hence $$DC = 2R \cos(\sin^{-1}(\frac{AB}{R})) = 2R \sqrt{1-\frac{AB^2

Thus required ratio becomes $$\frac{(k^{2} - 1)\left[\int_{r\frac {\sqrt {2}}{k}}^{2}\!dx\right]}{\int_{0}^{2}\!dx}$$ evaluating integral yields us needed fractional value.$$\frac{(k^{2} - 1)(2kr\frac{\sqrt{2}}{k}-rcot(\frac{rd}{kc})|}{2c}=$$simplification results ultimately giving expression as below :[][1]: https://latex.artofproblemsolving.com/b/a/f/baaffdd2ecbbaaf18bdbbeadfc3febaabefcbfaabbdeacdecbdcbccbcabaadddcdaaaeea%2Frendermath.svg

ost_step.1: Let one side length of the square equal 1 unit so $|OC|=r$, $|OB|=1$, thus since triangles $ABC$ and $BCD$ share base $BC$ as well as height r$\left(\begin{array}{l}AC\cdot BD=(AB)(CD)\\ AC=BD\\ AB=CD=a; AD= BC= k \\ {ab}\rightarrow ab={\frac{ak\cdot ak}{(1-(ka)^{2}}}\\ b^{2}-({ba})_{2}=c^{2} \end{array}\right.$ Step 2: To prove our statement let us consider a triangle ABC formed within Square ABCD such that angle CBA equals Angle DCA . If O lies inside Triangle ABC ,then |OD|<|DB| & |OC|<|CB| Thus ||DC|| > ||BO|| -------> ($|\overline{|DO}|<\overline{|DB}|$) && ($|\overline{|OC}|<\overline{|CB}|$). And Now using Pythagorean theorem,$ |\overline{|BD}^{2}|=|\overline{|BC}|^{2}+|\overline{|CD}|^{2},$$ x^{( }^{2}}=y^{( }

direct_answer.text:
To solve this problem, we need to determine the region around the origin, labeled \(O\), where every point is closer to \(O\) than to any vertex of the rectangle.

Step 1: Consider Rectangle \(ABCD\). Whenever you choose a random location somewhere inside rectangular area, chances are very high either your position won’t reach nearer toward corner (\(A,B,C,D\)) compared to midpoint of opposite sides because both width and length increase together due to constant ratio provided i.e., \(	ext{Area}_	ext{rectangle}\) increases proportionally when increasing radius while maintaining same aspect ratio also note here Area always remains fixed regardless whether changing dimensions keep them proportional keeping shape unchanged but making size changes accordingly henceforth,
given : Ratio w.r.t each other -> adjacent edges / diagonal edge value denoted through variable *k*
